POR.DRECONTENT:
Scattering theory describes the interaction of particles or waves with outside objects or with the medium through which they travel. For example, one might study the bounce of a billiard ball off the rail cushion at the edge of the table (particle scattering), or the reflection and refraction of light from the surface of a liquid (wave scattering).

In this project, I studied connections between particle and wave scattering. I studied how properties of the outside objects or medium which impede the progress of particles also impede (or fail to impede) the progress of waves, and vice versa. This is a central question in semiclassical analysis, the field which studies the mathematical relationship between quantum and classical physics.

In particular, one is interested in the relationship between trapping/escape of particles (particles being confined to a small region indefinitely/not being so confined) and decay of waves (waves disippating away, as do ripples in water). One asks: how do discontinuities and cusps (cusps are exponential narrowings) in the medium affect the decay of waves?

I showed that waves must decay at least a little whenever particles can escape at all, even in the presence of severe discontinuities in the medium.

I showed that cusps limit decay only slightly when they trap no particles at all. However, two undergraduate students (Kang and Kessler) and I showed that the combination of cusps and discontinuities limit decay substantially, even when they trap no particles.

Dyatlov and I showed that in negatively curved spaces (a setting important in general relativity and number theory, apart from its geometric interest), when no cusps occur, properties of resonances are finely linked to dynamical properties of scattering particles.
